Award.AbstractNarration: This award is made as part of the FY 2013 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Stefan Patrikis is "Arithmetic Aspects of the Langlands Program." The host institution for the fellowship is Harvard University, and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Benedict Gross.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Just as geometric objects--a square, a wallpaper pattern, a tetrahedron--possess symmetries (rotational, translational, etc.), so too do algebraic (polynomial) equations. Galois theory is the study of the symmetries of polynomial equations, and it is deeply connected to the most fundamental problems of number theory and arithmetic geometry. This research project was devoted to problems in Galois theory arising from basic questions in these fields. Its central goal was to establish evidence for, and examples of, the PI's ``generalized Kuga-Satake theory" conjecture; this goal was met in three papers, ``Generalized Kuga-Satake Theory and Rigid Local Systems, I: The Middle Convolution," ``Generalized Kuga-Satake Theory and Rigid Local Systems, II: Rigid Hecke Eigensheaves," and ``Generalized Kuga-Satake Theory and Good Reduction Properties of Galois Representations."

Algebraic varieties are the spaces of solutions to polynomial equations (in possibly many variables). The classical Kuga-Satake construction is a rather miraculous construction, dating from the late 60's, that takes a particular kind of variety (an abelian variety), and ingeniously constructs a new kind of variety (a K3 surface) that stands in a very particular (``motivic") Galois-theoretic relationship to the original abelian variety. The PI's conjecture, based on some of his previous study of Galois representations, is that an analogous construction should exist for any variety, not only for the special class of abelian varieties. This problem lies very deep, but the above-mentioned papers resulting from this project did produce many new examples of this ``Kuga-Satake" phenomenon, using entirely different techniques from those applicable in the setting of abelian varieties. The general problem remains a profitable source of interesting questions in algebraic and arithmetic geometry.

During the tenure of the fellowship, the PI completed a number of other unanticipated projects, all again relating Galois theory and number theory. Two of these papers were devoted to the deformation theory of Galois representations, one of the basic techniques in number theory ever since the proof of Fermat's Last Theorem. The techniques developed in these papers allowed the PI to resolve a decades-old problem on the possible ``symmetry groups" of Galois representations. These papers have also opened the door to the development of further techniques in the deformation theory of Galois representations, which the PI continues to pursue.
